cards.title: In pictures / Tom Jenkins' best images from day seven at Wimbledon
cards.rawTitle: Tom Jenkins' best images from day seven at Wimbledon

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: day seven
item.trailText: Guardian photographer Tom Jenkins is in SW19 to bring you his best images from a dramatic day
item.standFirst: Guardian photographer Tom Jenkins is in SW19 to bring you his best images from a dramatic day

displayImages.caption: Nick Kyrgios tosses his racket in the air during his defeat to France’s Richard Gasquet. During the match, Kyrgios received a code violation for swearing. He raged at ‘external bullshit’. He rowed with the umpire over whether he was taking too long to change his socks. He hurled his racket 10ft into the air.
displayImages.altText: Nick Kyrgios tosses his racket in the air during his defeat to France’s Richard Gasquet. During the match, Kyrgios got a code violation for swearing. He raged at ‘external bullshit’. He rowed with the umpire over whether he was taking too long to change his socks. He hurled his racket 10ft into the air.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Nick Kyrgios tosses his racket in the air during his defeat to France’s Richard Gasquet. During the match, Kyrgios received a code violation for swearing. He raged at ‘external bullshit’. He rowed with the umpire over whether he was taking too long to change his socks. He hurled his racket 10ft into the air.

displayImages.caption: Gasquet also lost it by smashing his racket into the ground. After the match, Gasquet spoke about Kyrgios’ antics: “He was a little bit angry, a little bit frustrated, I saw that. Sometimes it happens. He’s not the only one to do it. Even the best players in the world did it in the past.”
displayImages.altText: Richard Gasquet also lost it by smashing his racquet into the ground. After the match, Gasquet spoke about Kyrgios’ anitics: “He was a little bit angry, a little bit frustrated, I saw that. Sometimes it happens. He’s not the only one to do it. Even the best players in the world did it in the past.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Gasquet also lost it by smashing his racket into the ground. After the match, Gasquet spoke about Kyrgios’ antics: “He was a little bit angry, a little bit frustrated, I saw that. Sometimes it happens. He’s not the only one to do it. Even the best players in the world did it in the past.”

displayImages.caption: Kyrgios also hugged a ballboy. The Australian faces a heavy fine after apparently throwing a game in a sulk which provoked boos from the crowd. However, the player also won laughter when he broke off play to hug a ballboy on court.
displayImages.altText: Kyrgios also hugged a ballboy. The Australian faces a heavy fine after apparently throwing a game in a sulk which provoked boos from the crowd. However, the player also won laughter when he broke off play to hug a ballboy on court.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kyrgios also hugged a ballboy. The Australian faces a heavy fine after apparently throwing a game in a sulk which provoked boos from the crowd. However, the player also won laughter when he broke off play to hug a ballboy on court.

displayImages.caption: Serena Williams took on her sister Venus on Centre Court. She won in straight sets which provoked this response from Venus: “I don’t think she would call herself the greatest player of all time because she respects everyone else and the accomplishments they’ve made. But the level she’s playing at is unprecedented. I can say that with confidence. So make what you will of it.”
displayImages.altText: Serena Williams took on her sister Venus on Centre Court. She won in straight sets which provoked this response from Venus: “I don’t think she would call herself the greatest player of all time because she respects everyone else and the accomplishments they’ve made. But the level she’s playing at is unprecedented. I can say that with confidence. So make what you will of it.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Serena Williams took on her sister Venus on Centre Court. She won in straight sets which provoked this response from Venus: “I don’t think she would call herself the greatest player of all time because she respects everyone else and the accomplishments they’ve made. But the level she’s playing at is unprecedented. I can say that with confidence. So make what you will of it.”

displayImages.caption: Venus Williams measures up a return to Serena during her defeat. Serena prasied her sister graciously afterwards: “Venus was playing really well so it was good to get it done in straight sets. She has a game to just knock anyone’s socks off.”
displayImages.altText: Venus Williams measures up a return to Serena during her defeat. Serena prasied her sister graciously afterwards: “Venus was playing really well so it was good to get it done in straight sets. She has a game to just knock anyone’s socks off.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Venus Williams measures up a return to Serena during her defeat. Serena prasied her sister graciously afterwards: “Venus was playing really well so it was good to get it done in straight sets. She has a game to just knock anyone’s socks off.”

displayImages.caption: The sister come together at the end of the match. Serena now plays Victoria Azarenka of Belarus. “I’ve had a couple of tough matches with Victoria,” Serena said. “She’s due to win big”.
displayImages.altText: The sister come together at the end of the match. Serena now plays Victoria Azarenka of Belarus. “I’ve had a couple of tough matches with Victoria,” Serana said. “She’s due to win big".
displayImages.cleanCaption: The sister come together at the end of the match. Serena now plays Victoria Azarenka of Belarus. “I’ve had a couple of tough matches with Victoria,” Serena said. “She’s due to win big”.

displayImages.caption: Miguel Ángel Jiménez drifts off in the Royal Box during the Williams’ sisters match. Golfers Ian Poulter, Lee Westwood, Sam Torrance and Paul McGinley were also at Wimbledon unlike Rory McIlroy who was in crutches after rupturing ankle ligament playing football with friends in Bangor over the weekend.
displayImages.altText: Miguel Angel Jimenez drifts off in the Royal Box during the Williams’ sisters match. Golfers Ian Poulter, Lee Westwood, Sam Torrance and Paul McGinley were also at Wimbledon unlike Rory McIlroy who was in crutches after rupturing ankle ligament playing football with friends in Bangor over the weekend.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Miguel Ángel Jiménez drifts off in the Royal Box during the Williams’ sisters match. Golfers Ian Poulter, Lee Westwood, Sam Torrance and Paul McGinley were also at Wimbledon unlike Rory McIlroy who was in crutches after rupturing ankle ligament playing football with friends in Bangor over the weekend.

displayImages.caption: Next up on Centre Court was the fourth round match between Andy Murray and the 6ft 11in Ivo Karlovic of Croatia. Murray fashioned an artful, occasionally magnificent exhibition of defensive tennis to win 7-6, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4.
displayImages.altText: Next up on Centre Court was the fourth round match between Andy Murray and the 6ft 11in Ivo Karlovic of Croatia. Murray fashioned an artful, occasionally magnificent exhibition of defensive tennis to win 7-6, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Next up on Centre Court was the fourth round match between Andy Murray and the 6ft 11in Ivo Karlovic of Croatia. Murray fashioned an artful, occasionally magnificent exhibition of defensive tennis to win 7-6, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4.

displayImages.caption: The Centre Court crowd appreciate Murray’s performance. “I came up with some good lobs, passing shots, able to use the angles a bit more, trying to keep him from coming to the net so much,” Murray said at the end of the match.
displayImages.altText: The Centre Court crowd appreciate Murray's performance. “I came up with some good lobs, passing shots, able to use the angles a bit more, trying to keep him from coming to the net so much,” Murray said courtside at the end of the match.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Centre Court crowd appreciate Murray’s performance. “I came up with some good lobs, passing shots, able to use the angles a bit more, trying to keep him from coming to the net so much,” Murray said at the end of the match.

displayImages.caption: Murray celebrates after his victory. Murray has what should be a less physically demanding assignment in the quarter-finals against Vasek Pospisil, who has not taken a set off him in their three matches.
displayImages.altText: Murray celebrates after his victory. Murray has what should be a less physically demanding assignment in the quarter-finals against Vasek Pospisil, who has not taken a set off him in their three matches.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Murray celebrates after his victory. Murray has what should be a less physically demanding assignment in the quarter-finals against Vasek Pospisil, who has not taken a set off him in their three matches.

displayImages.caption: Novak Djokovic misses a return against Kevin Anderson. Djokovic went two sets down before fighting back.
displayImages.altText: Novak Djokovic misses a return against Kevin Anderson. Djokovic went two sets down before fighting back.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Novak Djokovic misses a return against Kevin Anderson. Djokovic went two sets down before fighting back.

displayImages.caption: Anderson had his day of days, routinely firing down pinpoint serves of 130 miles per hour and sending Djokovic scurrying in the relatively few rallies.
displayImages.altText: Kevin Anderson had his day of days, routinely firing down pinpoint serves of 130 miles per hour and sending Djokovic scurrying in the relatively few rallies.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Anderson had his day of days, routinely firing down pinpoint serves of 130 miles per hour and sending Djokovic scurrying in the relatively few rallies.

displayImages.caption: Djokovic struggled for two hours, until, two sets down and staring into the abyss, he galvanised himself. Simultaneously Anderson seemed to lose an inkling of energy and a modicum of belief. Djokovic lived to fight another day and they will resume for a one-set showdown after bad light suspended the match.
displayImages.altText: Djokovic struggled for two hours, until, two sets down and staring into the abyss, he galvanised himself. Simultaneously Anderson seemed to lose an inkling of energy and a modicum of belief. Djokovic lived to fight another day and they will resume for a one-set showdown after bad light suspended the match.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Djokovic struggled for two hours, until, two sets down and staring into the abyss, he galvanised himself. Simultaneously Anderson seemed to lose an inkling of energy and a modicum of belief. Djokovic lived to fight another day and they will resume for a one-set showdown after bad light suspended the match.

cards.title: Women's World Cup final 2015 / USA beat Japan 5-2

item.title: Women's World Cup final 2015: USA beat Japan 5-2
item.trailText: The best images as USA romped into an early lead before going on to utterly dominate against Japan in the Women’s World Cup final in Vancouver
item.standFirst: The best images as USA romped into an early lead before going on to utterly dominate against Japan in the Women’s World Cup final in Vancouver. Carli Lloyd scored a hat-trick, including a long-range shot from the halfway line, as Japan were blown away in Canada

displayImages.caption: USA fans outside the stadium Photograph: Lars Baron/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: USA fans outside the stadium before the match
displayImages.cleanCaption: USA fans outside the stadium
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Lars Baron/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: A Mountie waits to carry the Women’s World Cup on to the pitch Photograph: Matthew Lewis/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: A Royal Canadian Mounted Police officer waits to carry the FIFA Womens World Cup onto the pitch
displayImages.cleanCaption: A Mountie waits to carry the Women’s World Cup on to the pitch
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Matthew Lewis/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: A general view shows the BC Place Stadium before kick-off Photograph: Carmen Jaspersen/EPA
displayImages.altText: A general view shows the BC Place Stadium before kick-off
displayImages.cleanCaption: A general view shows the BC Place Stadium before kick-off
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Carmen Jaspersen/EPA

displayImages.caption: The USA players line up for the anthems Photograph: Stuart Franklin/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The players of USA line for the anthems
displayImages.cleanCaption: The USA players line up for the anthems
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Stuart Franklin/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Supporters kiss ahead the final Photograph: Franck Fife/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Supporters kiss ahead the final
displayImages.cleanCaption: Supporters kiss ahead the final
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Franck Fife/AFP/Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Carli Lloyd scores USA’s first goal despite the efforts of Japan goalkeeper Ayumi Kaihori Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Carli Lloyd scores USA’s first goal despite the efforts of Japan goalkeeper Ayumi Kaihori
displayImages.cleanCaption: Carli Lloyd scores USA’s first goal despite the efforts of Japan goalkeeper Ayumi Kaihori
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Carli Lloyd celebrates her goal as a stunned Mizuho Sakaguchi looks on Photograph: Maddie Meyer/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Carli Lloyd celebrates her goal as a stunned Mizuho Sakaguchi looks on
displayImages.cleanCaption: Carli Lloyd celebrates her goal as a stunned Mizuho Sakaguchi looks on
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Maddie Meyer/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Carli Lloyd of USA scores her second goal Photograph: Lars Baron/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Carli Lloyd of USA scores her second goal
displayImages.cleanCaption: Carli Lloyd of USA scores her second goal
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Lars Baron/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Lauren Holiday and Carli Lloyd celebrate the US’s 2-0 lead Photograph: Rich Lam/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Lauren Holiday and Carli Lloyd celebrate her second goal
displayImages.cleanCaption: Lauren Holiday and Carli Lloyd celebrate the US’s 2-0 lead
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Rich Lam/Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Japan’s Aya Sameshima is held back by Tobin Heath and Lauren Holiday Photograph: Erich Schlegel/USA Today Sports
displayImages.altText: Tobin Heath and Lauren Holiday
displayImages.cleanCaption: Japan’s Aya Sameshima is held back by Tobin Heath and Lauren Holiday
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Erich Schlegel/USA Today Sports

displayImages.caption: Holiday soon crashes home a sweet half-volley to make it 3-0! Photograph: Steven Limentani/ISI/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Holiday soon crashes home a sweet half-volley to make it 3-0!
displayImages.cleanCaption: Holiday soon crashes home a sweet half-volley to make it 3-0!
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Steven Limentani/ISI/Corbis

displayImages.caption: And then, out of nowhere ... what a goal! Lloyd shoots from the halfway line and catches the the Japanese keeper Kaihori way off her line. Kaihori slips as she runs back and the ball squirms into the net. Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.credit: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: And then, out of nowhere ... what a goal! Lloyd shoots from the halfway line and catches the the Japanese keeper Kaihori way off her line. Kaihori slips as she runs back and the ball squirms into the net.
displayImages.cleanCaption: And then, out of nowhere ... what a goal! Lloyd shoots from the halfway line and catches the the Japanese keeper Kaihori way off her line. Kaihori slips as she runs back and the ball squirms into the net.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Lloyd celebrates her hat-trick with goalkeeper Hope Solo and Megan Rapinoe Photograph: Michael Chow/USA Today Sports
displayImages.altText: Lloyd celebrates her hat-trick with goalkeeper Hope Solo and Megan Rapinoe
displayImages.cleanCaption: Lloyd celebrates her hat-trick with goalkeeper Hope Solo and Megan Rapinoe
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Michael Chow/USA Today Sports

displayImages.caption: Yuki Ogimi of Japan scores after a sweet turn inside the box to restore some hope for Japan. Photograph: Stuart Franklin/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Yuki Ogimi of Japan scores
displayImages.cleanCaption: Yuki Ogimi of Japan scores after a sweet turn inside the box to restore some hope for Japan.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Stuart Franklin/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: In the second half, Julie Johnston heads an own goal – so the score stands at 4-2 with just under 40 minutes to play. Are Japan going to pull off a miracle comeback? Photograph: Lars Baron/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: In the second half, Julie Johnston heads an own goal – so the score stands at 4-2 with just under 40 minutes to play. Are Japan going to pull off a miracle comeback?
displayImages.cleanCaption: In the second half, Julie Johnston heads an own goal – so the score stands at 4-2 with just under 40 minutes to play. Are Japan going to pull off a miracle comeback?
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Lars Baron/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Unlikely! Tobin Heath has made it 5-2. She’s pictured here celebrating her goal with Morgan Brian. Photograph: Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Tobin Heath has made it 5-2. She’s pictured here celebrating her goal with Morgan Brian.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Unlikely! Tobin Heath has made it 5-2. She’s pictured here celebrating her goal with Morgan Brian.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Japan’s goalkeeper Ayumi Kaihori saves under pressure (some of the pressure coming from her own team) Photograph: Nicholas Kamm/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Japan’s goalkeeper Ayumi Kaihori saves
displayImages.cleanCaption: Japan’s goalkeeper Ayumi Kaihori saves under pressure (some of the pressure coming from her own team)
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Nicholas Kamm/AFP/Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Johnston is challenged by Yuika Sugasawa Photograph: Lars Baron/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Johnston is challenged by Yuika Sugasawa
displayImages.cleanCaption: Johnston is challenged by Yuika Sugasawa
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Lars Baron/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Sawa Homare tackles Abby Wambach as the seconds tick down. Wambach, a veteran for USA, came on as a sub Photograph: Bob Frid/EPA
displayImages.altText: Sawa Homare tackles Abby Wambach
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sawa Homare tackles Abby Wambach as the seconds tick down. Wambach, a veteran for USA, came on as a sub
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Bob Frid/EPA

displayImages.caption: Carli Lloyd sinks to her knees as the final whistle blows Photograph: Michael Chow/USA Today Sports
displayImages.altText: Carli Lloyd celebrates as Rumi Utsugi reacts
displayImages.cleanCaption: Carli Lloyd sinks to her knees as the final whistle blows
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Michael Chow/USA Today Sports

displayImages.caption: Lloyd and O’Reilly celebrate at the final whistle Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Lloyd and O’Reilly celebrate at the final whistle
displayImages.cleanCaption: Lloyd and O’Reilly celebrate at the final whistle
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Meanwhile, Johnston drapes herself in the stars and stripes, and looks to the skies in celebration Photograph: Maddie Meyer/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Meanwhile, Johnston drapes herself in the stars and stripes, and looks to the skies in celebration
displayImages.cleanCaption: Meanwhile, Johnston drapes herself in the stars and stripes, and looks to the skies in celebration
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Maddie Meyer/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Heath and Morgan embrace Photograph: John Todd/ISI/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Heath and Morgan embrace
displayImages.cleanCaption: Heath and Morgan embrace
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: John Todd/ISI/Corbis

displayImages.caption: Sydney Leroux gets a kiss from husband Dom Dwyer Photograph: Franck Fife/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Sydney Leroux gets a kiss from husband Dom Dwyer
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sydney Leroux gets a kiss from husband Dom Dwyer
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Franck Fife/AFP/Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Wambach celebrates with her wife in the stands Photograph: Bob Frid/EPA
displayImages.altText: Abby Wambach celebrates with a friend in the stands
displayImages.cleanCaption: Wambach celebrates with her wife in the stands
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Bob Frid/EPA

displayImages.caption: Kelley O’Hara is still full of energy Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.credit: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Kelley O’Hara is still full of energy
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kelley O’Hara is still full of energy
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: And there it is: USA lift the trophy - the World Cup is theirs for a third time Photograph: Matthew Lewis/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: And there it is: USA lift the trophy - the World Cup is theirs for a third time
displayImages.cleanCaption: And there it is: USA lift the trophy - the World Cup is theirs for a third time
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Matthew Lewis/FIFA via Getty Images

image.caption: And then, out of nowhere ... what a goal! Lloyd shoots from the halfway line and catches the the Japanese keeper Kaihori way off her line. Kaihori slips as she runs back and the ball squirms into the net. Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
image.credit: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

cards.title: Sport picture of the day / Flying Nascar

item.title: Sport picture of the day: flying Nascar
item.trailText: Nascar driver Austin Dillon flies through the air before smashing into the barriers, wrecking his car
item.standFirst: Austin Dillon, driver of the No3 Bass Pro Shops Chevrolet, flies through the air before smashing into the barriers following the chequered flag during the Nascar Sprint Cup Series at the Daytona International Speedway in Florida. Dillon walked away from what was left of his car, waving to the crowd before being sent to hospital for further checks. Watch here

displayImages.altText: Austin Dillon, driver of the No3 Bass Pro Shops Chevrolet, flies through the air before smashing into the barriers following the checkered flag during the Nascar Sprint Cup Series at the Daytona International Speedway in Florida. Dillon walked away from what was left of his car, waving to the crowd before being sent to hospital for further checks
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Chris Graythen/Getty Images

headerImage.caption: Austin Dillon is involved in an on-track incident following the chequered flag at the Daytona International Speedway. Dale Earnhardt Jr won the race. Photograph: Chris Graythen/Getty Images
headerImage.altText: Austin Dillon is involved in an on-track incident following the chequered flag at the Daytona International Speedway. Dale Earnhardt Jr won the race.
headerImage.cleanCaption: Austin Dillon is involved in an on-track incident following the chequered flag at the Daytona International Speedway. Dale Earnhardt Jr won the race.

image.altText: Austin Dillon, driver of the No3 Bass Pro Shops Chevrolet, flies through the air before smashing into the barriers following the checkered flag during the Nascar Sprint Cup Series at the Daytona International Speedway in Florida. Dillon walked away from what was left of his car, waving to the crowd before being sent to hospital for further checks
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Chris Graythen/Getty Images

cards.title: In pictures / Tom Jenkins' best images from days five and six at Wimbledon
cards.rawTitle: Tom Jenkins' best images from days five and six at Wimbledon

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: days five and six
item.trailText: Guardian photographer Tom Jenkins is down in SW19 to bring you his best images from a dramatic last couple of days
item.standFirst: Guardian photographer Tom Jenkins is down in SW19 to bring you his best images from a dramatic last couple of days

displayImages.caption: Spectators on Murray Mount stand for the minute’s silence to remember the victims of the Tunisia beach attack.
displayImages.altText: Spectators on Murray Mount stand for the minute's silence to remember the victims of the Tunisia beach attack.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Spectators on Murray Mount stand for the minute’s silence to remember the victims of the Tunisia beach attack.

displayImages.caption: Bethanie Mattek-Sands puts ice on her neck during a break in her match with Belinda Bencic. Mattek-Sands, who frequently dyes her hair in a range of colours, said the tournament had ‘gotten a little excessive’ in its obsession with white, having tightened its rules last year to ban anything more than a 1cm coloured trim – even ruling out coloured underwear worn under white garments.
displayImages.altText: Bethanie Mattek-Sands puts ice on her neck during a break in her match with Belinda Bencic. Mattek-Sands, who frequently dyes her hair in a range of colours, said the tournament had “gotten a little excessive” in its obsession with white, having tightened its rules last year to ban anything more than a 1cm coloured trim – even ruling out coloured underwear worn under white garments.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Bethanie Mattek-Sands puts ice on her neck during a break in her match with Belinda Bencic. Mattek-Sands, who frequently dyes her hair in a range of colours, said the tournament had ‘gotten a little excessive’ in its obsession with white, having tightened its rules last year to ban anything more than a 1cm coloured trim – even ruling out coloured underwear worn under white garments.

displayImages.caption: A spectator hands Nick Kyrgios his racket after he flung it so forcefully into the grass that it bounced several metres into the terraces, narrowly missing someone. ‘I’m not the biggest believer in saying nothing out there or being a robot,’ Kyrgios said. ‘I feel you should express yourself. You know – it’s a sport.’
displayImages.altText: A spectator hands Nick Kyrgios his racket after he flung his racket so forcefully into the grass that it bounced several metres into the terraces, narrowly missing someone. “I’m not the biggest believer in saying nothing out there or being a robot,” Kyrgios said, “I feel you should express yourself. You know – it’s a sport.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: A spectator hands Nick Kyrgios his racket after he flung it so forcefully into the grass that it bounced several metres into the terraces, narrowly missing someone. ‘I’m not the biggest believer in saying nothing out there or being a robot,’ Kyrgios said. ‘I feel you should express yourself. You know – it’s a sport.’

displayImages.caption: Kyrgios went on to defeat No7 seed Milos Raonic and said afterwards, ‘I’m focusing but at the same time I’m having fun. When I find that balance, I play some really good tennis. I thought I was doing that today in the second, third and fourth.’
displayImages.altText: Nick Kyrgios went on to defeat No7 seed Milos Raonic and said afterwards, “I’m focusing but at the same time I’m having fun. When I find that balance, I play some really good tennis. I thought I was doing that today in the second, third and fourth.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kyrgios went on to defeat No7 seed Milos Raonic and said afterwards, ‘I’m focusing but at the same time I’m having fun. When I find that balance, I play some really good tennis. I thought I was doing that today in the second, third and fourth.’

displayImages.caption: Novak Djokovic slides to return the ball to Bernard Tomic as the world No1 recorded a 6-3, 6-3, 6-3 victory that was utterly ruthless. Tomic was generous in his praise. “I can’t even describe it in words,” he said. “Too good, too good.”
displayImages.altText: Novak Djokovic slides to return the ball to Bernard Tomic as the world No1 recorded a 6-3, 6-3, 6-3 victory that was utterly ruthless. Tomic was generous in his praise. “I can’t even describe it in words,” he said. “Too good, too good.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Novak Djokovic slides to return the ball to Bernard Tomic as the world No1 recorded a 6-3, 6-3, 6-3 victory that was utterly ruthless. Tomic was generous in his praise. “I can’t even describe it in words,” he said. “Too good, too good.”

displayImages.caption: Heather Watson cannot reach a Serena Williams serve during her defeat on Centre Court. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by Serena in a dramatic final set.
displayImages.altText: Heather Watson can't reach a Serena Williams serve during her defeat on Centre Court. Watson pushed the five-time Wimbledon champion to the very brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by Serena in a dramatic final set.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Heather Watson cannot reach a Serena Williams serve during her defeat on Centre Court. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by Serena in a dramatic final set.

displayImages.caption: Williams is emotional as she celebrates her victory over Watson. ‘What’s the toughest away match to play?’ Williams was asked afterwards. ‘A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?’ She didn’t think for long. ‘I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain. For sure.’
displayImages.altText: Serena Williams is emotional as she celebrates her victory over Heather Watson. “What’s the toughest away match to play?” Williams was asked afterwards. “A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?” She didn’t think for long. “I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain. For sure.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Williams is emotional as she celebrates her victory over Watson. ‘What’s the toughest away match to play?’ Williams was asked afterwards. ‘A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?’ She didn’t think for long. ‘I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain. For sure.’

displayImages.caption: Watson waves to the crowd after her defeat to Williams. ‘It was a tough, tough ask today, but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards, ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’
displayImages.altText: Heather Watson waves to the crowd after her defeat to Serena Williams. “It was a tough, tough ask today, but I was super-, super-close,” Watson said afterwards, “I think that’s what really hurts the most.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Watson waves to the crowd after her defeat to Williams. ‘It was a tough, tough ask today, but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards, ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’

displayImages.caption: Dustin Brown fails to reach a return during his defeat to Viktor Troicki. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’
displayImages.altText: Dustin Brown fails to reach a return during his defeat to Viktor Troicki. He reflected on his week: “When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dustin Brown fails to reach a return during his defeat to Viktor Troicki. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’

displayImages.caption: A multiple exposure of Sam Groth serving in his defeat to Roger Federer. Groth’s serve of 147mph during the match was the second fastest ever recorded at Wimbledon.
displayImages.altText: A multiple exposure of Sam Groth serving in his defeat to Roger Federer. Groth’s serve of 147mph during the match was the second fastest ever recorded at Wimbledon.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A multiple exposure of Sam Groth serving in his defeat to Roger Federer. Groth’s serve of 147mph during the match was the second fastest ever recorded at Wimbledon.

displayImages.caption: James Ward returns during his five-set defeat to Vasek Pospisil. An heroic failure almost matching Heather Watson’s. Both British players though left the stage with a lot more credit in the bank than they arrived with.
displayImages.altText: James Ward returns during his five set defeat to Vasek Pospisil. An heroic failure almost matching Heather Watson’s. Both British players though left the stage with a lot more credit in the bank than they arrived with.
displayImages.cleanCaption: James Ward returns during his five-set defeat to Vasek Pospisil. An heroic failure almost matching Heather Watson’s. Both British players though left the stage with a lot more credit in the bank than they arrived with.

displayImages.caption: The last British singles player still standing was again Andy Murray. Here, he returns the ball to Andreas Seppi on Centre Court during his four-set win.
displayImages.altText: The last British singles player still standing was again Andy Murray. Here, he returns the ball to Andreas Seppi on Centre Court during his four set win.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The last British singles player still standing was again Andy Murray. Here, he returns the ball to Andreas Seppi on Centre Court during his four-set win.

displayImages.caption: Murray had to come through a lot of drama to beat Seppi on the sixth evening of the 2015 championships. Both players required medical attention for injuries. ‘Towards the end of the second set my right shoulder started to tighten up,’ Murray said courtside. ‘When he took that injury break it cooled down a bit. I thought I played very well. There was that part of the second set where I struggled but the way I finished the match is the way I want to play the rest of the tournament, with a lot of energy.’
displayImages.altText: Andy Murray had to come through a lot of drama to beat Andreas Seppi on the sixth evening of the 2015 championships. Both players required medical attention for injuries. “Towards the end of the second set my right shoulder started to tighten up,” Murray said courtside. “When he took that injury break it cooled down a bit. I thought I played very well. There was that part of the second set where I struggled but the way I finished the match is the way I want to play the rest of the tournament, with a lot of energy.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Murray had to come through a lot of drama to beat Seppi on the sixth evening of the 2015 championships. Both players required medical attention for injuries. ‘Towards the end of the second set my right shoulder started to tighten up,’ Murray said courtside. ‘When he took that injury break it cooled down a bit. I thought I played very well. There was that part of the second set where I struggled but the way I finished the match is the way I want to play the rest of the tournament, with a lot of energy.’

image.altText: Spectators on Murray Mount stand for the minute's silence to remember the victims of the Tunisia beach attack.
image.cleanCaption: Spectators on Murray Mount stand for the minute’s silence to remember the victims of the Tunisia beach attack.

image.caption: Heather Watson cannot reach a Serena Williams serve during her defeat on Centre Court. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by Serena in a dramatic final set.
image.altText: Heather Watson can't reach a Serena Williams serve during her defeat on Centre Court. Watson pushed the five-time Wimbledon champion to the very brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by Serena in a dramatic final set.
image.cleanCaption: Heather Watson cannot reach a Serena Williams serve during her defeat on Centre Court. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by Serena in a dramatic final set.

image.caption: Williams is emotional as she celebrates her victory over Watson. ‘What’s the toughest away match to play?’ Williams was asked afterwards. ‘A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?’ She didn’t think for long. ‘I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain. For sure.’
image.altText: Serena Williams is emotional as she celebrates her victory over Heather Watson. “What’s the toughest away match to play?” Williams was asked afterwards. “A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?” She didn’t think for long. “I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain. For sure.”
image.cleanCaption: Williams is emotional as she celebrates her victory over Watson. ‘What’s the toughest away match to play?’ Williams was asked afterwards. ‘A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?’ She didn’t think for long. ‘I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain. For sure.’

image.caption: Watson waves to the crowd after her defeat to Williams. ‘It was a tough, tough ask today, but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards, ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’
image.altText: Heather Watson waves to the crowd after her defeat to Serena Williams. “It was a tough, tough ask today, but I was super-, super-close,” Watson said afterwards, “I think that’s what really hurts the most.”
image.cleanCaption: Watson waves to the crowd after her defeat to Williams. ‘It was a tough, tough ask today, but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards, ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’

image.caption: Dustin Brown fails to reach a return during his defeat to Viktor Troicki. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’
image.altText: Dustin Brown fails to reach a return during his defeat to Viktor Troicki. He reflected on his week: “When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.”
image.cleanCaption: Dustin Brown fails to reach a return during his defeat to Viktor Troicki. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’

image.caption: A multiple exposure of Sam Groth serving in his defeat to Roger Federer. Groth’s serve of 147mph during the match was the second fastest ever recorded at Wimbledon.
image.altText: A multiple exposure of Sam Groth serving in his defeat to Roger Federer. Groth’s serve of 147mph during the match was the second fastest ever recorded at Wimbledon.
image.cleanCaption: A multiple exposure of Sam Groth serving in his defeat to Roger Federer. Groth’s serve of 147mph during the match was the second fastest ever recorded at Wimbledon.

image.caption: James Ward returns during his five-set defeat to Vasek Pospisil. An heroic failure almost matching Heather Watson’s. Both British players though left the stage with a lot more credit in the bank than they arrived with.
image.altText: James Ward returns during his five set defeat to Vasek Pospisil. An heroic failure almost matching Heather Watson’s. Both British players though left the stage with a lot more credit in the bank than they arrived with.
image.cleanCaption: James Ward returns during his five-set defeat to Vasek Pospisil. An heroic failure almost matching Heather Watson’s. Both British players though left the stage with a lot more credit in the bank than they arrived with.

image.caption: The last British singles player still standing was again Andy Murray. Here, he returns the ball to Andreas Seppi on Centre Court during his four-set win.
image.altText: The last British singles player still standing was again Andy Murray. Here, he returns the ball to Andreas Seppi on Centre Court during his four set win.
image.cleanCaption: The last British singles player still standing was again Andy Murray. Here, he returns the ball to Andreas Seppi on Centre Court during his four-set win.

image.caption: Murray had to come through a lot of drama to beat Seppi on the sixth evening of the 2015 championships. Both players required medical attention for injuries. ‘Towards the end of the second set my right shoulder started to tighten up,’ Murray said courtside. ‘When he took that injury break it cooled down a bit. I thought I played very well. There was that part of the second set where I struggled but the way I finished the match is the way I want to play the rest of the tournament, with a lot of energy.’
image.altText: Andy Murray had to come through a lot of drama to beat Andreas Seppi on the sixth evening of the 2015 championships. Both players required medical attention for injuries. “Towards the end of the second set my right shoulder started to tighten up,” Murray said courtside. “When he took that injury break it cooled down a bit. I thought I played very well. There was that part of the second set where I struggled but the way I finished the match is the way I want to play the rest of the tournament, with a lot of energy.”
image.cleanCaption: Murray had to come through a lot of drama to beat Seppi on the sixth evening of the 2015 championships. Both players required medical attention for injuries. ‘Towards the end of the second set my right shoulder started to tighten up,’ Murray said courtside. ‘When he took that injury break it cooled down a bit. I thought I played very well. There was that part of the second set where I struggled but the way I finished the match is the way I want to play the rest of the tournament, with a lot of energy.’
